title: Sea, Green and Brown, Maine

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of watercolor with wiping and scraping, and with opaque watercolor, over graphite, on medium-weight (estimated), moderately textured, ivory wove paper (all edges trimmed), laid down on wood-pulp board faced with ivory wove (estimated) paper, gilt with silver leaf, and backed with dark red wove paper, in original frame.

description: This unusually somber watercolor must have been painted indoors on a dark day or possibly at nightfall, when the sea appeared almost black. Marin captured this view from the glass porch of the Cape Split house at high tide, when the large triangular rock known as the tide marker was barely visible; the tip of a coastal ledge juts into the picture at the left. The artist here used directional wiping, blending in opaque watercolor. Movement and brightness were introduced by scraping away pigment to reveal the white paper, conjuring the breaking surf playing about the submerged rocks.
medium_display: Watercolor with wiping and scraping, and with opaque watercolor, over graphite, on medium-weight (estimated), moderately textured, ivory wove paper (all edges trimmed), laid down on wood-pulp board faced with ivory wove (estimated) paper, gilt with silver leaf, and backed with dark red wove paper, in original frame
inscriptions: Signed and dated lower right corner, in watercolor over graphite: ”Marin 37”
publication_history:
American Art Research Council, no. 41-X (Whitney).

Sheldon Reich, John Marin, Ph.D. diss. (University of Iowa, 1966), p. 421, fig. 293.

Sheldon Reich, John Marin: A Stylistic Analysis and Catalogue Raisonné I (Tucson, Ariz., 1970), p. 196, fig. 167.

Sheldon Reich, John Marin: A Stylistic Analysis and Catalogue Raisonné II (Tucson, Ariz., 1970), p. 687, no. 37.18 (ill).
exhibition_history:
Washington, D.C., National Gallery of Art, "Modern Art and America, Alfred Stieglitz and His New York Galleries,” Jan. 28–Apr. 22, 2001, pp. 355, 359, and 534, pl. 130.

Art Institute of Chicago, "John Marin's Watercolors: A Medium for Modernism," Jan. 19-Apr. 17, 2011, pp. 74-75, 162, 164-65, 177, figs. 63a & 64, pl. 81; traveled to the High Museum, Atlanta, June 26-Sept. 11, 2011.
provenance_text: Alfred Stieglitz (1864–1946), New York; Stieglitz Estate (Georgia O'Keeffe (1887–1986), executor); given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1949.
